newsitem.title: GERMANY: German debt, futures underpinned by German data.
newsitem.headline: German debt, futures underpinned by German data.

text.p: German Bunds and futures were slightly lower in afternoon dealings on Thursday, hurt by profit-taking but underpinned by support from ongoing sluggish German economic conditions, traders said.

At 1445 GMT, DTB March Bund futures were down two basis points at 102.11 points after reaching a new contract high at 102.34 after German unemployment in January reached a new post-war record at 4.66 million.
The 10-year benchmark cash Bund due January 2007 was at 102.29, yielding 5.69 percent and below Wednesday's closing level of 102.38 points.
Traders expected range trade on Friday as the market consolidated recent gains tied to the weak economic outlook and for March futures to remain between 101.80 and 102.35.
"We could see some more gains if the unemployment reports keep coming in so poorly," said one trader. "But for now the lack of new impulses will keep the market relatively quiet."
Traders saw 101.92 points as a critical level for March Bund futures, with a close below that level likely prompting more profit-taking, traders said.
"It's shaping up to be a decisive level for the market," said one Frankfurt trader.

Despite falling German debt yields, traders said the market generally did not expect a Bundesbank rate cut in the near-term. The German central bank opted to keep rates steady at a council meeting on Thursday.
"The Bundesbank lowering German interest rates is not going to wipe away unemployment nor will it help the mark against the dollar," said one trader.
On a technical basis, traders looked for March futures to find support at 101.72 and 101.53, while resistance is evident at the contract high of 102.34.
